name: Pythagoras
description: Philosopher and mathematician who founded the Pythagorean school; contributions to mathematics, music theory, and philosophy. His theorem remains fundamental to geometry.

name: Heraclitus
description: Pre-Socratic philosopher known for his doctrine of change and the concept of Logos; famous for the statement that one cannot step into the same river twice.

name: Parmenides
description: Pre-Socratic philosopher who argued that reality is unchanging and that change is illusory; founder of the Eleatic school.

name: Socrates
description: Athenian philosopher who laid foundations of Western philosophy through his Socratic method; never wrote but known through Plato's dialogues. Executed by hemlock for impiety.

name: Hippocrates
description: Father of Medicine who established medicine as a profession distinct from philosophy and religion; the Hippocratic Oath bears his name.

name: Democritus
description: Pre-Socratic philosopher who developed atomic theory, proposing that all matter consists of indivisible atoms moving through void.

name: Thucydides
description: Athenian historian whose History of the Peloponnesian War set standards for historical scholarship with critical analysis and evidence-based writing.

name: Plato
description: Student of Socrates and teacher of Aristotle; founded the Academy in Athens. His dialogues and theory of Forms profoundly shaped Western philosophy.

name: Aristotle
description: Student of Plato and tutor of Alexander the Great; his works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, politics, and natural sciences dominated Western thought for millennia.

name: Demosthenes
description: Greatest Athenian orator whose speeches against Philip II of Macedon exemplified classical rhetoric and Athenian resistance to Macedonian expansion.

name: Euclid
description: Mathematician whose Elements became the most influential textbook in history; systematized geometry and established rigorous mathematical proof.

name: Archimedes
description: Mathematician, physicist, and engineer who discovered principles of buoyancy and leverage; invented war machines to defend Syracuse. Killed during Roman siege.

name: Eratosthenes
description: Polymath who calculated Earth's circumference with remarkable accuracy; coined the term "geography" and created early world maps.

name: Leonidas I
description: Spartan king who led 300 Spartans in heroic last stand at Thermopylae against Persian forces, becoming symbol of courage and sacrifice.

name: Pericles
description: Athenian statesman during the Golden Age; promoted democracy, arts, and architecture including the Parthenon. His funeral oration exemplifies democratic ideals.

name: Alexander the Great
description: King of Macedon who created one of history's largest empires, spreading Hellenistic culture from Greece to India. Never lost a battle.

name: Philip II of Macedon
description: Father of Alexander the Great; transformed Macedon into the dominant Greek power through military innovation and diplomatic skill.

name: Cyrus the Great
description: Founder of the Achaemenid Persian Empire; known for religious tolerance and the Cyrus Cylinder, earliest declaration of human rights.

name: Darius I
description: Achaemenid emperor who reorganized the empire with satrapies, standardized coinage, and built the Royal Road. Invaded Greece but defeated at Marathon.

name: Xerxes I
description: Persian king who led massive invasion of Greece; defeated at Salamis and Plataea. Known from Herodotus's Histories and Biblical Book of Esther.

name: Mani
description: Prophet and founder of Manichaeism, a major Gnostic religion blending Zoroastrian, Christian, and Buddhist elements that spread from Rome to China.

name: Scipio Africanus
description: Roman general who defeated Hannibal at Zama, ending the Second Punic War and establishing Roman dominance in the Mediterranean.

name: Cato the Elder
description: Roman statesman and historian who championed traditional Roman values and advocated destruction of Carthage with his famous "Carthago delenda est."

name: Cicero
description: Roman statesman, orator, and philosopher whose writings on rhetoric, politics, and philosophy shaped Latin prose and Western thought.

name: Julius Caesar
description: Roman general and statesman who conquered Gaul, crossed the Rubicon, and became dictator. His assassination led to end of the Republic.

name: Marcus Antonius (Mark Antony)
description: Roman general and triumvir; formed alliance with Cleopatra VII, defeated by Octavian at Actium, ending the Roman Republic.

name: Cleopatra VII
description: Last active pharaoh of Ptolemaic Egypt; formed political and romantic alliances with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony to preserve Egyptian independence.

name: Augustus (Octavian)
description: First Roman Emperor who ended civil wars and established the Pax Romana. His 40-year reign transformed Rome from republic to empire.

name: Tiberius
description: Second Roman Emperor, stepson of Augustus; capable administrator but reclusive ruler. Reigned during Jesus Christ's crucifixion.

name: Nero
description: Fifth Roman Emperor notorious for tyranny, persecution of Christians, and possibly setting the Great Fire of Rome. His suicide ended the Julio-Claudian dynasty.

name: Vespasian
description: Roman Emperor who restored stability after Year of Four Emperors; began construction of Colosseum and reformed finances.

name: Trajan
description: Roman Emperor who expanded the empire to its greatest extent; renowned for administrative ability and philanthropic public works.

name: Hadrian
description: Roman Emperor who built Hadrian's Wall and the Pantheon; promoted Greek culture and traveled extensively throughout the empire.

name: Marcus Aurelius
description: Roman Emperor and Stoic philosopher; his Meditations remains a classic of philosophy. Last of the Five Good Emperors.

name: Diocletian
description: Roman Emperor who divided the empire into the Tetrarchy, reformed administration, and launched the last great persecution of Christians.

name: Constantine the Great
description: First Christian Roman Emperor who legalized Christianity with the Edict of Milan and founded Constantinople. Convened Council of Nicaea.

name: Julian the Apostate
description: Roman Emperor who attempted to restore paganism and traditional Roman religion after Constantine's Christianization; died fighting Persia.

name: Theodosius I
description: Last emperor to rule both Eastern and Western Roman empires; made Christianity the state religion and banned pagan practices.

name: Virgil
description: Roman poet whose Aeneid became Rome's national epic, glorifying Roman origins and Augustus's rule. Also wrote Eclogues and Georgics.

name: Horace
description: Roman lyric poet known for his Odes, Satires, and Epistles; his phrase "carpe diem" (seize the day) endures.

name: Ovid
description: Roman poet famous for Metamorphoses, a narrative poem of Greek and Roman mythology that profoundly influenced Western art and literature.

name: Seneca the Younger
description: Stoic philosopher, statesman, and tutor to Nero; his philosophical writings and tragedies influenced medieval and Renaissance thought.

name: Plutarch
description: Greek historian and biographer whose Parallel Lives compared Greek and Roman leaders, profoundly influencing Western literature and biography.

name: Tacitus
description: Roman historian whose Annals and Histories provided critical accounts of the Roman Empire; known for concise, powerful prose.

name: Ptolemy (Claudius Ptolemaeus)
description: Mathematician, astronomer, and geographer whose geocentric model dominated astronomy for 1400 years. His Geography mapped the known world.

name: Galen
description: Physician whose theories dominated Western medicine for 1300 years; made advances in anatomy, physiology, and pharmacology.

name: Jesus Christ
description: Central figure of Christianity; Jewish preacher whose teachings on love, forgiveness, and salvation formed the basis of Christian theology.

name: Paul the Apostle
description: Early Christian missionary whose epistles comprise much of the New Testament; transformed Christianity from Jewish sect to world religion.

name: Augustine of Hippo
description: Bishop and theologian whose works including Confessions and City of God shaped Christian doctrine and Western philosophy.

name: Phidias
description: Greatest sculptor of classical Greece; created the statue of Zeus at Olympia (one of Seven Wonders) and supervised Parthenon sculptures.

name: Praxiteles
description: Greek sculptor who pioneered naturalistic and graceful style; famous for Aphrodite of Knidos, first major nude female statue.

name: Homer
description: Epic poet attributed with composing the Iliad and Odyssey, foundational works of Western literature. Historical existence debated but influence undeniable.
